results.title: Finale
results.creator_credit: Michael Darlow, Robert Bas, Theodora Olembert and Triangle Productions
results.brief_description: A nostalgic look at the Marlborough Music Hall in North London. It was demolished and we see this being done interspersed with photographs of the famous music hall stars who played there and their special acts.

results.title: The Final hour of Joan of Arc
results.creator_credit: Bernard Girard, James Fonda, Columbia Broadcasting System and Young America Films
results.brief_description: One of the “You are There” television series, which reconstructs the events of 29th and 30th May, 1431, at Rouen. Spurred on by the English, who wish to ensure that Joan does not revive the campaign against them, the Church authorities press the interrogation of Joan, and next day have her burnt at the stake as a “lapsed heretic”. Includes Dianna Lynn as Joan. Written for television by Milton Geiger; director of photography by Ed Fitzgerald and narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Final game
results.brief_description: A stirring account of the championship game played by the Boston Celtics, internationally-known champions of professional basketball, against their challengers, the Cincinnati Royals. Using a variety of cinetechniques this film captures this exciting, graceful game.

results.title: The Films of George Melies 1861 to 1938
results.brief_description: The French pioneer Georges Melies made films from 1896 to 1913. This compilation has three parts. Part one includes “The Vanishing lady” his first trick film; “The Brahmin and the buttefly”; “Indiarubber head” and “Reproduction: coronation ceremonies. Part Two incudes: “A Trip to the moon”; “The Mysterious box” and “The Marvellous wreath”. Part Three: “The Melomaniacs”; “The Bewitched trunk”; “The Four hundred tricks of the devil” and “The Knight of the black art”.

results.title: Una Filma di
results.brief_description: Designed to promote the Australian Universities Drama Festival. Shows the diverse reactions to an advertising poster ranging from hysteria and swooning to police action. Includes an early appearance by Max Gillies. Written by John Dawson. Music by George Tibbits.

results.title: Film tactics
results.brief_description: A vivid and humorous presentation of how to use sound films to the best effect, and the various results of different kinds of failures on the part of the instructor using a sound film.

results.title: Film problems
results.brief_description: This film presents problems arising when filming a person walking into a room to talk to someone. Explains that certain effects can be created in the minds of an audience by the way the sequence is filmed and edited. Uses animation and live action to illustrate examples of variation achieved by changes in camera movement and placement, composition of scene, and cutting during or at junction points of action. The film concludes with scenes selected to form a sequence for audience interpretation.

results.title: Film making
results.brief_description: Films designed for school orientated learning have brought a new impact and excitement to learning previously unavailable in the classroom. In this investigation, the actual production of such a film is followed from beginning to finished product. It goes from covering the idea, script, costing, cameraman, director, crew, actors, titles, lettering, animation, editing, narration and music.

results.title: [Film for practice No. 04]
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: A Film for Discussion
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Martha Ansara and Sydney Women's Film Group
results.brief_description:
The Sydney Women’s Film Group was formed in 1971 by a small group of feminists who were troubled by the lack of options for women filmmakers in Australia, and appalled by the depiction of women in the media. The group produced and distributed films, held screenings and discussions, ran production workshops for women, and lobbied for women’s access to film funding and education. “Our aim was to further the spread of our revolutionary ideas through the visual media” (Jeni Thornley). Many of Australia’s women filmmakers owe their inspiration or start to this seminal group’s activities.

‘A Film for Discussion’ is the group’s first production, and is possibly the first feminist film made in Australia. The juxtaposition of experimental and realist sequences in the depiction of a ‘day in the life’ of an ordinary young woman, parallels the ‘personal is political’ ethos of 1970s feminism.
